item.title: PLOSBiology
item.description: The ability to rapidly relearn memories after forgetting has been ascribed to long-term #MemoryFormation. @AlkisMH &co show that rapid #relearning instead arises from fast new learning of short-term temporally-volatile memory #PLOSBiology https://plos.io/44bikeP

item.title: sarahtaber
item.description:
New podcast episode!

This one‚Äôs a deep dive on the US food system during Jim Crow, how Southern landowners used starvation to control Black and poor white farm workers, and how that laid the groundwork for the food system we have today.

https://shows.acast.com/farm-to-taber/episodes/king-cotton-jim-crow-and-pellagra

#food #history #agriculture

item.title: tuthill
item.description:
Some major updates to our @biorxivpreprint on how proprioceptors in the fly leg sense and topographically encode distinct stimulus features (joint position, movement, vibration).

Among other things, we collected a single-cell RNA-seq dataset of fly leg proprioceptors, in collaboration with Hongjie Li's lab at Baylor. We found that all proprioceptor subtypes express similar levels of mechanosensory, K+, and Na+ channels, suggesting that channel expression is not sufficient to explain subtype feature selectivity. This strengthens our conclusion that biomechanical differences are the key determinant of proprioceptor feature selectivity in the fly leg.

#neuroscience #Drosophila

https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2022.08.08.503192v2

item.title: Snoro
item.description:
Despite Its Giant Footprint, the Climate Impact of Meat is Still Largely Misunderstood: Survey

A recent survey finds consumers in five major meat-consuming nations are still largely in the dark about its climate impact

A recent global poll by Northstar Research, commissioned by sustainable food NGO Madre Brava, revealed that citizens in Brazil, France, Germany, the U.K., and the U.S. do not consider industrial meat production a leading cause of climate change

https://www.greenqueen.com.hk/climate-impact-of-meat-survey/

#Climate

item.title: ct_bergstrom
item.description:
There's a certain poetry to the narrative.

1. a group of ideologues submit a terrible paper about how science is too woke

2. it gets rejected because it is crap

3. they feel feel horribly aggrieved because surely they are entitled to publish this shit where ever they choose

4. these subaltern voices‚Äîsilenced victims of cancel culture‚Äîair their grievances in the NY TImes, WSJ, etc

5. the whole episode disproves their thesis. In science, if not op-ed pages, quality clearly still matters

item.title: Neurograce
item.description:
Children can perform as well as adults on a repeat-detection task using object or motion stimuli (though they are slower). Yet they don't show the same neural modulations in object- and motion-processing brain regions based on which type of stimulus is the target of the detection task.

#neuroscience
https://www.jneurosci.org/content/early/2023/04/12/JNEUROSCI.0159-23.2023.abstract

item.title: Neurograce
item.description: Note: I am very consciously avoiding the word "attention" here, as I strive to use more "methodology-based" language to avoid baking in assumed neural mechanisms. See this nice paper on theory-based vs. methodological language in attention (though could apply anywhere): https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S001002772200302X?via%3Dihub

Academic Journals are Broken. Let‚Äôs Build a Better Scientific Record.

The content is heartbreaking, but it was lovely and encouraging to talk with folks working to change things

item.title: taf
item.description:
I‚Äôve recently learned of a different way of limiting corporate travel, and I think it‚Äôs brilliant.

Every company travel policy I‚Äôd heard of until yesterday has been a variation on the same theme:

There‚Äôs an annual a travel budget. Management may or may not have priority and there may be limitations on who can travel together, but in the end the true limit is the amount of money in the budget.

The policy I learned of yesterday is almost, but not quite, unlike the others. The budget isn‚Äôt about money. It‚Äôs about CO2 emissions. Each department gets a specific amount of CO2 emissions for travel for the year.

The implications are interesting:

Travel within Europe has become train first as a natural consequence. Intercontinental travel has been reduced by a significant amount.

It‚Äôs an absolutely amazing policy and it should be the standard corporate travel policy everywhere.

item.title: internic
item.description: @petersuber Open access is certainly desirable, no author fees obviously sounds good, and I agree that if it would be better if journals were not-for-profit ventures, but I'm unclear how the significant work performed by the journal staff will be funded if we remove both embargoes and author fees.
